17  package com.okta.sdk.cache;
18  
19  import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;
20  
21  /**
22   * Builder for creating simple {@link CacheManager} instances <b>suitable for SINGLE-JVM APPLICATIONS</b>.  If your
23   * application is deployed (mirrored or clustered) across multiple JVMs, you might not
24   * want to use this builder and use your own clusterable CacheManager implementation instead.  See Clustering below.
25   * <h1>Clustering</h1>
26   * <b>The default CacheManager instances created by this Builder DO NOT SUPPORT CLUSTERING</b>.
27   * <p>
28   * If you use this Builder and your application is deployed on multiple JVMs, <b>each of your application instances will
29   * have <em>their own</em> local cache of Okta data</b>.  Depending on your application requirements, and your
30   * cache TTL and TTI settings, this could introduce a significant difference in cached data seen by your application
31   * instances, which would likely impact user management behavior.  For example, one application instance could see an
32   * account as ENABLED, but the other application instance could see it as DISABLED.
33   * <p>
34   * For some applications, this discrepancy might be an acceptable trade-off, especially if you configure
35   * {@link #withDefaultTimeToIdle(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit) timeToIdle} and
36   * {@link #withDefaultTimeToLive(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit) timeToLive} settings low enough.  For example,
37   * maybe a TTL of 5 or 10 minutes is an acceptable time to see 'stale' account data.  For other applications, this might
38   * not be acceptable.  If it is acceptable, configuring the timeToIdle and timeToLive settings will allow you to
39   * fine-tune how much variance you allow.
40   * <p>
41   * However, if you are concerned about this difference in data and you want the Okta SDK's cache to be coherent
42   * across your application nodes (typically a good thing to have), it is strongly recommended that you do not use this
43   * Builder and instead configure the Okta SDK with a clustered {@code CacheManager} implementation of your choosing.
44   * This approach still gives you excellent performance improvements and ensures that your cached data is coherent (seen
45   * as the same) across all of your application instances.
46   * <p>
47   * This comes with an increased cost of course: setting up a caching product and/or cluster.  However, this is not
48   * much of a problem in practice: most multi-instance applications already leverage caching clusters for their own
49   * application needs. In these environments, and with a proper {@code CacheManager} implementation leveraging a
50   * clustered cache, the Okta Java SDK will live quite happily using this same caching infrastructure.
51   * <p>
52   * A coherent cache deployment ensures all of your application instances/nodes can utilize the same cache policy and
53   * see the same cached security/identity data.  Some example clustered caching solutions: Hazelcast,
54   * Ehcache+Terracotta, Memcache, Redis, Coherence, GigaSpaces, etc.
55   *
56   * @since 0.5.0
57   */
58  public interface CacheManagerBuilder {
59  
60      /**
61       * Sets the default Time to Live (TTL) for all cache regions managed by the {@link #build() built}
62       * {@code CacheManager}. You may override this default for individual cache regions by using the
63       * {@link #withCache(CacheConfigurationBuilder) withCache} for each region you wish to configure.
64       * <p>
65       * Time to Live is the amount of time a cache entry may exist after first being created before it will expire and no
66       * longer be available.  If a cache entry ever becomes older than this amount of time (regardless of how often
67       * it is accessed), it will be removed from the cache as soon as possible.
68       * <p>
69       * If this value is not configured, it is assumed that cache entries could potentially live indefinitely.
70       * Note however that entries can still be expunged due to other conditions (e.g. memory constraints, Time to
71       * Idle setting, etc).
72       * <h1>Usage</h1>
73       * <pre>
74       *     ...withDefaultTimeToLive(30, TimeUnit.MINUTES)...
75       *     ...withDefaultTimeToLive(1, TimeUnit.HOURS)...
76       * </pre>
77       *
78       * @param ttl      default Time To Live scalar value
79       * @param timeUnit default Time to Live unit of time
80       * @return the builder instance for method chaining.
81       */
82      CacheManagerBuilder withDefaultTimeToLive(long ttl, TimeUnit timeUnit);
83  
84      /**
85       * Sets the default Time to Idle (TTI) for all cache regions managed by the {@link #build() built}
86       * {@code CacheManager}. You may override this default for individual cache regions by using the
87       * {@link #withCache(CacheConfigurationBuilder) withCache} for each region you wish to configure.
88       * <p>
89       * Time to Idle is the amount of time a cache entry may be idle (unused / not accessed) before it will expire and
90       * no longer be available.  If a cache entry is not accessed at all after this amount of time, it will be removed
91       * from the cache as soon as possible.
92       * <p>
93       * If this value is not configured, it is assumed that cache entries could potentially live indefinitely.
94       * Note however that entries can still be expunged due to other conditions (e.g. memory constraints, Time to
95       * Live setting, etc).
96       * <h1>Usage</h1>
97       * <pre>
98       *     ...withDefaultTimeToLive(30, TimeUnit.MINUTES)...
99       *     ...withDefaultTimeToLive(1, TimeUnit.HOURS)...
100      * </pre>
101      *
102      * @param tti      default Time To Idle scalar value
103      * @param timeUnit default Time to Idle unit of time
104      * @return the builder instance for method chaining.
105      */
106     CacheManagerBuilder withDefaultTimeToIdle(long tti, TimeUnit timeUnit);
107 
108     /**
109      * Adds configuration settings for a specific Cache region managed by the {@link #build() built}
110      * {@code CacheManager}, like the region's Time to Live and Time to Idle.
111      *
112      * @param builder the CacheConfigurationBuilder instance that will be used to a cache's configuration.
113      * @return this instance for method chaining.
114      */
115     CacheManagerBuilder withCache(CacheConfigurationBuilder builder);
116 
117     /**
118      * Returns a new {@link CacheManager} instance reflecting Builder's current configuration.
119      *
120      * @return a new {@link CacheManager} instance reflecting Builder's current configuration.
121      */
122     CacheManager build();
123 }
